may.translation[0].definitions[0].defini: if something may happen or may be true, there is a possibility that it will happen or be true but this is not certain
may.translation[0].definitions[0].exampl: I may be late, so don’t wait for me.
Some chemicals may cause environmental damage.
There may not be enough money to pay for the repairs.
Well, I may have been wrong.
They may have called while you were out.
It may be that Minoan ships were built and repaired here.
Your job may well involve some travelling  (=it is fairly likely).
may.translation[0].definitions[1].defini: if something may be done, completed etc in a particular way, that is how it is possible to do it
may.translation[0].definitions[1].exampl: The problem may be solved in a number of different ways.
may.translation[0].definitions[2].defini: used to say that someone is allowed to do something
may.translation[0].definitions[2].exampl: Thank you. You may go now.
There is a set of rules to show what members may and may not do.
You may sit down or stand, just as you wish.
No one may own more than 10% of the shares.
may.translation[0].definitions[3].defini: used to ask politely for permission to do something
may.translation[0].definitions[3].exampl: May I come in and wait?
May we use your office for a few minutes?
may.translation[0].definitions[4].defini: used to say, ask, or suggest something in a polite way
may.translation[0].definitions[4].exampl: All these things, if I may say so, are entirely irrelevant.
Who, may I ask, is Wotherspoon?
May I suggest that you consider the matter further before taking any action.
may.translation[0].definitions[5].defini: used to say that even though one thing is true, something else which seems very different is also true
may.translation[0].definitions[5].exampl: I may be slow, but at least I don’t make stupid mistakes.
Although this may sound like a simple process, great care is needed.
Strange as it may seem, I always felt I belonged here.
may.translation[0].definitions[6].defini: used after ‘so that’ or ‘in order that’ to say that someone does something in order to make something else possible
may.translation[0].definitions[6].exampl: The hero sacrifices his life so that his friend may live.
You say May I? when asking for permission
May I ask you a question?
You say you may when giving someone permission
You say that something may happen or be true
He may be in his office
You say that something may have happened
They may have already gone home
You use may not in negative sentences
I may not be here much longer
He may not have understood what you said
In everyday English, you can use might in the same way as may to say that something is possible
that something might happen or be true
He might be in his office
They might have already gone home
In everyday English, you can also use might not or mightn’t
I might not be here much longer
may.translation[1].definitions[0].defini: the white or pink flowers of the hawthorn
may.translation[2].definitions[0].defini: the fifth month of the year, between April and June
may.translation[2].definitions[0].exampl: She started work here last May.
We don’t have any meetings on May 6th, do we?
An agreement was signed on 6th May 1977.
